016package tech.uom.seshat;
017
018import java.util.Objects;
019import javax.measure.Unit;
020import javax.measure.Quantity;
021import javax.measure.UnconvertibleException;
022import javax.measure.UnitConverter;
023import javax.measure.quantity.Time;
024import javax.measure.quantity.Angle;
025import javax.measure.quantity.Length;
026import javax.measure.format.ParserException;
027import tech.uom.seshat.resources.Errors;
028
029
030/**
031 * Provides static methods working on {@link Quantity} instances.
032 * Seshat implementation of quantities has the following characteristics:
033 *
034 * <ul>
035 *   <li>Values are stored with {@code double} precision.</li>
036 *   <li>All quantities implement the specific subtype (e.g. {@link Length} instead of {@code Quantity<Length>}).</li>
037 *   <li>Quantities are immutable, {@link Comparable} and {@link java.io.Serializable}.</li>
038 * </ul>
039 *
040 * @author  Martin Desruisseaux (Geomatys)
041 * @version 1.1
042 * @since   1.0
043 */
044public final class Quantities {
045    /**
046     * Do not allow instantiation of this class.
047     */
048    private Quantities() {
049    }
050
051    /**
052     * Creates a quantity for the given value and unit of measurement symbol.
053     * This is a convenience method that combines a call to {@link Units#valueOf(String)}
054     * with {@link #create(double, Unit)}.
055     *
056     * @param  value  the quantity magnitude.
057     * @param  unit   symbol of the unit of measurement associated to the given value.
058     * @return a quantity of the given type for the given value and unit of measurement.
059     * @throws ParserException if the given symbol can not be parsed.
060     */
061    public static Quantity<?> create(final double value, final String unit) {
062        return create(value, Units.valueOf(unit));
063    }
064
065    /**
066     * Creates a quantity for the given value and unit of measurement.
067     *
068     * @param  <Q>    the quantity type (e.g. {@link Length}, {@link Angle}, {@link Time}, <i>etc.</i>).
069     * @param  value  the quantity magnitude.
070     * @param  unit   the unit of measurement associated to the given value.
071     * @return a quantity of the given type for the given value and unit of measurement.
072     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the given unit class is not a supported implementation.
073     *
074     * @see UnitServices#getQuantityFactory(Class)
075     */
076    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Q create(final double value, final Unit<Q> unit) {
077        Objects.requireNonNull(unit);
078        final Unit<Q> system = unit.getSystemUnit();
079        if (system instanceof SystemUnit<?>) {
080            final UnitConverter c = unit.getConverterTo(system);
081            final ScalarFactory<Q> factory = ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).factory;
082            if (c.isLinear()) {
083                /*
084                 * We require arithmetic operations (A + B, A * 2, etc.) to be performed as if all values were
085                 * converted to system unit before calculation. This is mandatory for preserving arithmetic laws
086                 * like associativity, commutativity, etc.  But in the special case were the unit of measurement
087                 * if related to the system unit with only a scale factor (no offset), we get equivalent results
088                 * even if we skip the conversion to system unit.  Since the vast majority of units fall in this
089                 * category, it is worth to do this optimization.
090                 *
091                 * (Note: despite its name, above `isLinear()` method actually has an `isScale()` behavior).
092                 */
093                if (factory != null) {
094                    return factory.create(value, unit);
095                } else {
096                    final Class<Q> type = ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).quantity;
097                    if (type != null) {
098                        return ScalarFallback.factory(value, unit, type);
099                    } else {
100                        /*
101                         * This cast should be safe because `type` should be null only in contexts where the user
102                         * can not expect a more specific type. For example it may be the result of an arithmetic
103                         * operation, in which case the return value in method signature is `Quantity<?>`.
104                         */
105                        @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
106                        final Q quantity = (Q) new Scalar<>(value, unit);
107                        return quantity;
108                    }
109                }
110            }
111            /*
112             * If the given unit of measurement is derived from the system unit by a more complex formula
113             * than a scale factor, then we need to perform arithmetic operations using the full path
114             * (convert all values to system unit before calculation).
115             */
116            if (factory != null) {
117                final Q quantity = factory.createDerived(value, unit, system, c);
118                if (quantity != null) {
119                    return quantity;
120                }
121            }
122            final Class<Q> type = ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).quantity;
123            if (type != null) {
124                return DerivedScalar.Fallback.factory(value, unit, system, c, type);
125            } else {
126                @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")  // Same reason than for `new Scalar(…)`.
127                final Q quantity = (Q) new DerivedScalar<>(value, unit, system, c);
128                return quantity;
129            }
130        } else {
131            throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.UnsupportedImplementation_1, unit.getClass()));
132        }
133    }
134
135    /**
136     * Returns the given quantity as an instance of the specific {@code Quantity} subtype.
137     * For example this method can be used for converting a {@code Quantity<Length>} to a {@link Length}.
138     * If the given quantity already implements the specific interface, then it is returned as-is.
139     *
140     * @param  <Q>      the quantity type (e.g. {@link Length}, {@link Angle}, {@link Time}, <i>etc.</i>), or {@code null}.
141     * @param  quantity the quantity to convert to the specific subtype.
142     * @return the given quantity as a specific subtype (may be {@code quantity} itself), or {@code null} if the given quantity was null.
143     * @throws IllegalArgumentException if the unit class associated to the given quantity is not a supported implementation.
144     */
145    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")
146    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Q castOrCopy(final Quantity<Q> quantity) {
147        if (quantity != null) {
148            final Unit<Q> unit   = quantity.getUnit();
149            final Unit<Q> system = unit.getSystemUnit();
150            if (!(system instanceof SystemUnit<?>)) {
151                throw new IllegalArgumentException(Errors.format(Errors.Keys.UnsupportedImplementation_1, unit.getClass()));
152            }
153            final Class<Q> type = ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).quantity;
154            if (!type.isInstance(quantity)) {
155                final ScalarFactory<Q> factory = ((SystemUnit<Q>) system).factory;
156                final double value = AbstractConverter.doubleValue(quantity.getValue());
157                if (factory != null) {
158                    return factory.create(value, unit);
159                } else {
160                    return ScalarFallback.factory(value, unit, type);
161                }
162            }
163        }
164        return (Q) quantity;
165    }
166
167    /**
168     * Returns the smallest of two quantities. Values are converted to {@linkplain Unit#getSystemUnit() system unit}
169     * before to be compared. If one of the two quantities is {@code null} or has NaN value, then the other quantity
170     * is returned. If the two quantities have equal converted values, then the first quantity is returned.
171     *
172     * @param  <Q>  type of quantities.
173     * @param  q1   the first quantity (can be {@code null}).
174     * @param  q2   the second quantity (can be {@code null}).
175     * @return the smallest of the two given quantities.
176     *
177     * @since 1.1
178     */
179    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Quantity<Q> min(final Quantity<Q> q1, final Quantity<Q> q2) {
180        return minOrMax(q1, q2, false);
181    }
182
183    /**
184     * Returns the largest of two quantities. Values are converted to {@linkplain Unit#getSystemUnit() system unit}
185     * before to be compared. If one of the two quantities is {@code null} or has NaN value, then the other quantity
186     * is returned. If the two quantities have equal converted values, then the first quantity is returned.
187     *
188     * @param  <Q>  type of quantities.
189     * @param  q1   the first quantity (can be {@code null}).
190     * @param  q2   the second quantity (can be {@code null}).
191     * @return the largest of the two given quantities.
192     *
193     * @since 1.1
194     */
195    public static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Quantity<Q> max(final Quantity<Q> q1, final Quantity<Q> q2) {
196        return minOrMax(q1, q2, true);
197    }
198
199    /**
200     * Implementation of {@link #min(Quantity, Quantity)} and {@link #max(Quantity, Quantity)}.
201     */
202    @SuppressWarnings("unchecked")      // For `((Comparable) v1).compareTo(v2)` which is checked by `if` statement.
203    private static <Q extends Quantity<Q>> Quantity<Q> minOrMax(final Quantity<Q> q1, final Quantity<Q> q2, final boolean max) {
204        if (q1 == null) return q2;
205        if (q2 == null) return q1;
206        final Unit<Q> u1 = q1.getUnit();
207        final Unit<Q> u2 = q2.getUnit();
208        final Unit<Q> s1 = u1.getSystemUnit();
209        final Unit<Q> s2 = u2.getSystemUnit();
210        if (!Objects.equals(s1, s2)) {
211            throw new UnconvertibleException((String) null);
212        }
213        Number v1 = u1.getConverterTo(s1).convert(q1.getValue());
214        Number v2 = u2.getConverterTo(s2).convert(q2.getValue());
215        if (isNaN(v2)) return q1;
216        if (isNaN(v1)) return q2;
217        final int c;
218        if (v1.getClass().isInstance(v2) && v1 instanceof Comparable<?>) {
219            c = ((Comparable) v1).compareTo(v2);
220        } else {
221            c = Double.compare(v1.doubleValue(), v2.doubleValue());
222        }
223        return (max ? c >= 0 : c <= 0) ? q1 : q2;
224    }
225
226    /**
227     * Returns {@code true} if the given number is null or NaN.
228     * Current implementation recognizes {@link Float} and {@link Double} types.
229     *
230     * @param  value  the number to test (may be {@code null}).
231     * @return {@code true} if the given number is null or NaN.
232     *
233     * @see Float#isNaN()
234     * @see Double#isNaN()
235     *
236     * @since 1.1
237     */
238    private static boolean isNaN(final Number value) {
239        if (value == null) return true;
240        if (value instanceof Double) return ((Double) value).isNaN();
241        if (value instanceof Float)  return ((Float)  value).isNaN();
242        return false;
243    }
244}
